description: From Middle English turnyng, turnynge, from Old English tyrning, turnung, equivalent to trun +‎ -ing.

entries.meaning: (Britain) A turn or deviation from a straight course.
examples: Take the second turning on the left.

entries.meaning: (field hockey) At hockey, a foul committed by a player attempting to hit the ball who interposes their body between the ball and an opposing player trying to do the same.
The shaping of wood or metal on a lathe.
(plural only) Shavings produced by turning something on a lathe.
examples: The turnings get into your trouser turnups!

description: From Middle English turninge, turnynge, turninde, turnand, turnende, from Old English tyrnende, turniende, present participle of Old English tyrnan, turnian (“to turn”). Equivalent to turn +‎ -ing.

examples: The Earth is turning about its axis as we speak.
He made wooden soldiers by turning them on a hand lathe.
